- - - EXAMINATION
Good morning, Ms. Rice.  My name is Devon Sereda.  I am one of the attorneys representing the defendants in this matter. Have you ever had your deposition taken before?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm going to give you a few instructions to make today go smoothly, okay? We have a court reporter sitting between us. She is taking down everything that you and I say.  For that reason, it's important that all your responses be verbal. It's easy in everyday conversation to nod, shrug your shoulders, say uh-uh or uh-huh, but that won't make a clear record. If you do that I'm going to give you a quick reminder that we need a verbal response, okay?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It's easy in everyday conversation to anticipate where my question is going and start to answer before my question is done, but that makes her job harder.  Try to let me finish my question before you start your answer.  If for any reason I cut off your answer and started my next question, let me know, so I can make sure we get your full answer on the record.
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm sure your attorney has advised you of this, but we want to make sure you don't guess at any answers today.  If I ask you a question and you don't know the answer or you don't remember the answer, those are perfectly acceptable responses, as long as that's the truth, okay?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: There may be questions that I ask you to estimate time or distance.  Once again, I don't want you to guess, but if you feel like you're able to make an estimate, go ahead and do so.  Just let me know you're making an estimate, okay? I'm pretty quick at taking depositions, but if at any time you need to take a break, use the restroom, speak with your attorney, whatever it may be, I'm happy to give you that time.  I just ask, if there is a question pending, that you answer that question before we take our break, okay?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: If I ask a question and you don't understand it, be sure to let me know, because if you answer the question, I'm going to assume you understood it.  If any part of my question seems unclear, just let me know. I'll be happy to rephrase it so it is clear, okay?

Cars that's in the middle of, I guess you can say, I Street coming from Eerie can turn onto Hunting Park going towards G and Hunting Park.  My light had the pedestrian walk sign.  So the number signs never came up at the time I was crossing the street when he turned that white van going onto Hunting Park going towards G and Hunting Park.  At the time I got hit, it was literally in the middle of the street.

On the other side, you have where the 89 is going down towards M and Hunting Park to make a turn onto Castor Avenue, that bus route. The cars are going both ways in the intersection. text: There are two lanes in between the double lines.  Two cars can go down Hunting Park going towards G Street, and on the opposite side there is two cars that can go towards Castor Avenue from Hunting Park. When the car turned from I Street on the opposite direction, he has to make a wider turn onto Hunting Park to get towards G and Hunting Park.  You have to look between ongoing traffic because you have cars going down I Street going towards I and Eerie. Then the cars coming from the opposite way on I Street can go towards I and Bristol going towards I and Cayuga where those cars can make a right or left turn. It's a park right in front of the street.  You have to be mindful of the oncoming traffic because cars are going this way and this way.

text: As he's turning real quick, I turn around.  I'm like, what the fuck, and I fall on my knees.  I break my fall with my hands. I tilted over.  He rushes out the car, drags me from the street back to the corner where I initially came from.  I'm on the ground, and he says, I'm sorry, I'm sorry.

text: - - - EXAMINATION
Ms. Rice, my name is Cheryl Garber. I'm with Garber Law.  I'm personal counsel for Pro-Coat Painters. Good morning.
speaker: MS. GARBER

text: Good morning.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: While on the topic, I have a couple questions for you. When you said Mr. Torres said I'm sorry, I'm sorry, was he speaking in English or Spanish?
speaker: MS. GARBER

text: He said, I sorry, I sorry, I sorry, just like that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you say that he grabbed you under your arms and dragged you to the corner, can you describe that for me a little bit more. Can you tell me were your feet on the ground?  Were your knees on the ground? What was the lower portion of your body doing when he assisted you to the corner?
speaker: MS. GARBER

text: When I fell on my knees, I tilted over a little bit, and Mr. Torres got out of the car.  He rushed because he was in a panic, you could tell; eyes bulging open.  I was in a panic because I was scared. He grabbed me under the cuff of my underarms and dragged me on the sidewalk of which I first initially came from when I was trying to walk across the street.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is it fair to say your feet were sort of on the ground being drug along? You weren't being drug on your knees; it wasn't ruining your clothes, right?
speaker: MS. GARBER

text: I got drug from my back.  The back of the heels of my shoes, my clogs, were dragging.  My jacket was a three-quarter length.  It came to my knees basically.  The bottom part of my jacket was dragging on the ground.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You mentioned your clogs.  Can you tell me a little more. What did they look like?  Did they have a wedge heel?  Did they have a heel heel?
speaker: MS. GARBER

text: They're pink clogs, like nursing clogs for support for my feet.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What does the heel look like?
speaker: MS. GARBER

text: They're just a brown clog heel.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is there a separation in between the heel and the middle of the shoe on the bottom or is it all one piece?
speaker: MS. GARBER

text: No, it's all one piece.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you, ma'am.
speaker: MS. GARBER

text: - - - EXAMINATION
You indicated that it was raining out. Was the roadway wet?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Yes, it was wet.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I know this happened in January. Was there any snow on the ground or ice?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: It was slushy.  The night before was that temperature where it was icy.  That morning when it was raining, the rain broke some of the ice, so it made it slushy.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You said that he takes you to the sidewalk. Are you standing at this point, sitting?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: I'm sitting down on the ground.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How are you sitting?  Are you sitting Indian style?  Are you sitting off the curb? How are you sitting?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: With my back towards the pole, and I'm sitting on the ground on my butt.  There is a pole right there on the corner of I Street.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are you aware of any witnesses to the accident other than the three people that were in the other vehicle and your daughter; anybody that came up to you and said, hey, I saw this happen?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Nobody came up.  They just was looking.  Everybody gave their two cents, but it was early in the morning.  Everybody was trying to get to work.  People trying to get their kids to school.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did the vehicle actually push you to the ground, or did you fall from the surprise?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: No, it pushed me to the ground because he was trying to stop.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How do you know he was trying to stop?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Because you heard the skrrt, that part.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You heard the screech of brakes?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You said you said what the fuck and were surprised. How much time passed between when you saw something was about to happen and the impact actually occurring?  Was it instantaneous, or was there a few seconds that went by?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: I didn't even have a few seconds because when I'm walking across the street and he's turning and it starts to count 23, 22 seconds and before I even reach that double-yellow line, before I knew it, the car just said boom.  I turned around, and it's right when I'm on my knees.  I'm like, what the fuck?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Prior to you starting to cross the street when you were still on the corner, did you see his vehicle at that point?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: I really wasn't paying attention because the little pedestrian walk thing was up, and the light was green.  My recollection is I can walk across the street.  I'm not going to cross the street on a red or yellow light.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How would you describe the force of the impact from the vehicle?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: It was hard to the point where my daughter was crying, so it was hard enough.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Just to be clear, your daughter was not hit by the vehicle, correct?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You said that the police did not come to the scene. Did you call the police?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you have a cell phone on you at the time?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you carrying anything at the time when the incident occurred?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Just a pocketbook.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What kind of pocketbook was it?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Just a shoulder bag.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did anybody else come to the scene?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: My sister came.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What's your sister's name?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Jasma, J-A-S-M-A.  Same last name, Rice.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How soon after the accident did she come to the scene?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Right after, like five, ten minutes. She had to walk from my mom's house to I Street.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that the only person that you knew that came to the scene of the accident?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did any ambulance personnel come to the scene?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Yes.  Hold on.  They came, but they came about 15, 20 minutes later.  Clothes was drenched wet.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Your clothes?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Yes, pants and jacket was wet.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What did you tell the EMS personnel when they came?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: My daughter was hysterical.  I've never been hit by a car before.  She's like, Mom, Mom, can we get to the hospital a different way.  I was like I'm not going to get in the ambulance right now.  They were like, are you sure?  You look a little disoriented.  I was like I'm okay, I'm okay. They started talking to Mr. Torres, but there was a language barrier.  The skinny guy was trying to translate.  After that, I went back to my mom's house, changed my clothes because I was wet and didn't want to go to the hospital wet, and I went to the ER.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You said your pants and your jacket were wet?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: My pants were wet.  My jacket was wet.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You said it was wet. Was it wet in the back, in the front, the entire jacket?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: The back of my jacket was wet, but after laying on the ground, my whole jacket was wet.  It had black spots on it and everything.  It was a cream-colored jacket.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was your daughter still crying and upset when the EMS personnel got there?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: I just told her to relax before they even got there.  I'm like, relax, call Titi, which is my sister.  I'm okay, I'm okay.  I'm fine.  She didn't go to school that day.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was she still crying when the ambulance personnel came?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: No, she was just breathing heavy, shocked.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you have any other conversation with anybody else at the scene?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Any more attempts at conversation with Mr. Torres?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: No, he was just like, I'm sorry, I'm sorry, I'm sorry.  The other guy was translating.  I was like you really hurt my knees.  How did you not see me?  He kept saying, I sorry, I sorry. Then when I was like how did you hit me, he kept saying no se, no se, no se.  Then the skinny guy was translating to him what I said.  Then Mr. Torres spoke back to him in Spanish, and I just asked what is you saying. Mr. Torres called, I guess, his supervisor at Pro-Coat, and the skinny guy gave me the information of Pro-Coat, the name of the company, his name and the boss' name and that's it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long would you say you were actually at the scene for?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: I was there for a long time.  Police never came.  I wound up going to the 24th/25th District to make a report.  The information that Mr. Torres gave me that day, I filed a report with that information.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When did you go to the district?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: That same day.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: After the emergency room?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: No, no, before I went to the emergency room.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you go home first, change your clothes, and then go to the police office?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: No, I went to the police station first, made the report.  They gave me the report number.  I went home, just threw on some sweatpants and went to the emergency room.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Which ER did you go to?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Elkins Park.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you tell the EMS personnel what was bothering you?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: I told them my knees hurt, and I said I'm just in pain.  But at that time that day, when I tried to break my fall with the cuff of my hands, those were hurting me.  I had a little bruise because I'm light, so I had a bruise there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you tell the EMS personnel about your hands or just your knees?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Well, they could see it because I was showing them.  They were like, are you okay? Are you sure you're okay?  The short EMS lady thought I was a little disoriented and was like, are you sure you're okay?  I said I'm okay.  I just want to make sure my daughter is okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you see any damage to the van from the impact?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: To tell you the truth, I didn't look.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You went to Elkins Park for the ER. Is that Aria?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Einstein.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What did you tell them your complaints were when you went to Einstein?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: When you initially go through admissions, they asked me what's the reason I was here.  I said I was hit by a vehicle, gave the information that Mr. Torres gave me. After that, they said what's going on.  I showed them my hands and my knees.  I got an x-ray. At the time, they asked for my insurance information.  I waited, and they were like you have some swelling in your knees but it's nothing we can do.  Try to put an ice pack on it.  They put an ice pack on my hands.  They were like, by tomorrow, you may feel soreness and things like that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You said swelling. Was the swelling in both knees?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What did they take x-rays of?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: They took x-rays of my knees and my back.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Why your back?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Because I told them it was hurting.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You didn't mention that before, so that's why I'm asking that. You told them your hands were hurting, your back, and knees?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was it your upper back, middle back, lower back, whole back?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Lower back.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When did that start hurting you?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: It was just a sharp pain.  I was just like, what the hell?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was that immediately after the accident, or did it develop?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: No, it happened maybe an hour or two after.  It was just like a soreness, I guess, from just the dragging and just the shock or whatever.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did they discuss the results of the x-rays with you?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: They said they couldn't find anything. My knees showed swelling or whatnot but that was about it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I think you said you had bruising on your hands?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Yeah, I had bruising on my hands, right here at the bottom.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Indicating the heel of your hand?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you take any photographs of the bruising?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: No, I wasn't thinking about that -- hold on.  I did on my daughter's phone, but she switched phones.  I couldn't find those pictures.  My daughter had took a picture of the license plate of the van.  When she accompanied me at the ER before I went in the x-ray, she did take a picture of the palms of my hands.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You no longer have those?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: I just can't find them because through Google photographs and this is a new phone that she received, so we just couldn't locate the pictures.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long were you at the hospital for?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Hours.  From 10:30 -- hold on.  I got to think.  Probably approximately 9:30, and I didn't get discharged until about 2:00 or 3:00.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You said they told you to put ice on both your hands and knees?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did they give you any other discharge instructions?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: They just said follow up with my primary physician, follow up with physical therapy, if needed.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When is the next time you sought medical treatment?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Approximately, the end of January, the beginning of February.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where did you go?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Philly Spine Center on North Broad Street.  Then I went to Philly Spine Center on Cottman Avenue.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Why the gap in treatment?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Because I don't have no more time left at work.  I have two children.  I have to be a mom, as well.  You have to deal with the pain and just go on with life.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you first went to Philly Spine Center, were your complaints the same; your hands, low back, and knees?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: When I went to North Broad Street, my knees were very agitated and hurting. Basically, I was always an active person.  I did ballet for 18 years.  I never had any type of knee pain, back pain, or anything like that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It was just your knees?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: It was knee pain, back pain.  I just did at-home exercises.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Prior to going there?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Prior; take baths with Epsom salt, doctor Teal's Epsom Salt.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How did you come about treating with Philly Spine?  How did you find the facility?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: I spoke to an attorney in regard to the accident.  After that, I was referred to Philly Spine Center.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What did they do for you there at Philly Spine?  What kind of treatment?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Just physical therapy treatment, like back treatment, knee treatment.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What specifically?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Just exercise of the back, vibration, hands on, a vibrating massage thing, walking exercises, exercises with my knees.  They gave me a paper of what I can do at home to try to take down the pressure of knee pain and things like that.  I told them what I was doing at home before I even got to them.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How often were you going for treatment?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Two to three times a week.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long would each visit last?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Probably like a half-hour.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How many months did you treat with Philly Spine?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: February 2018 to -- I don't remember. I think in 2019.  The one on Cottman Avenue released me, I think, in March or April 2019. I don't really remember off hand, but approximately around that time.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Your recollection is you were treating up until this past spring?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was there any break in that treatment at Philly Spine?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Of course, I would miss some days because I have children, so most likely I have to miss days.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Any large gaps between the end of January beginning of February 2018?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: It wasn't too big of a gap, but, yes, I would miss some days out of the week. Sometimes I would go one day out of the week, sometimes I would go two.  I have to do homework.  I have to cook.  I have to work. I have to pay bills.  I have to be a mom.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did they send you out for any diagnostic testing?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: I went to MRI Diagnostics.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You had an MRI done?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You had an EMG. Didn't somebody come to Cottman Avenue and do an EMG?
speaker: MR. MCCANDLESS

text: I had an EMG, but I had an MRI done on Roosevelt Boulevard, that diagnostic place where I sit in the chair and they did an MRI.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Of what body parts?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: They did it of my lumbar spine, cervical.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Why your cervical?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: That's just what the doctor ordered.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you have any neck complaints?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Sometimes I had neck complaints, but that's what he ordered.  When I went, I was like, Doc, I felt like it was a shooting nerve pain, and I never had this before.  To be honest, I didn't have it the day of the accident, but maybe a week or two later I started having this sharp pain in my neck shooting up and down my neck.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Your lumbar spine, your cervical spine. Any other body parts they did an MRI of?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: If they did, I don't know.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Nothing of your knees?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: I don't remember.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You said an EMG was done at Philly Spine?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Yes, on Cottman Avenue.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was there a doctor that came in the facility to do the EMG?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was it a male or female doctor?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: A male.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did they discuss the results of the EMG with you?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: No, he told me that the doctor was going to discuss that with me.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did he ever?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What did he tell you?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Oh, I don't remember.  I don't remember.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How about the MRI, did anyone discuss the results of the MRI with you?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What did they tell you?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: They said I had a disc bulge in my back of my L5, L6 or something like that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Anything else they told you about the MRIs?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: They said it was swelling around the tissue in my back.  It showed an aggravated nerve.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you stopped going to Philly Spine, were you discharged, or did you voluntarily stop going?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: No, the doctor discharged me.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: I went to MRCP.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When did you go to MRCP?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: When did I go to MRCP?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You can't ask him.  I just want to know what your memory is.
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: I don't remember.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But it was after Philly Spine?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: It was after Philly Spine.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was it fairly recently?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: No, it wasn't recently.  It was a couple months ago.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long did you go to MRCP for?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: I went to the one downtown.  I went to the one up the boulevard.  I went to MRCP downtown maybe about two or three times. Then I was referred to the one on Roosevelt Boulevard.  I went there about twice.  Then after that I didn't have time to go back.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Who referred you there?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: MRCP downtown, Dr. Yang.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Who is Dr. Yang?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: She's the doctor at MRCP.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Who referred you to MRCP?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: My attorney.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What kind of treatment were you getting at MRCP?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Just therapy treatment, exercises to exercise my knee and my back, because they asked me what was my complaints.  I told them that off and on periodically my knees pain me, and I never had those issues before.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did the physical therapy that you received at Philly Spine improve your pain at all?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: After a couple months, it improved a little because I wasn't having consistent pain in my knees.  It's seven days out of the week.  My knees were paining me more so four to five days out of the week where I was taking Epsom salt baths to help me and Motrin to help me.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you were discharged from treatment at Philly Spine, were you still having back and knee pain?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Neck pain?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Had it improved from when you first went to Philly Spine?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: A little.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How about the treatment you received at MRCP, did that help with your pain at all?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: A little.  Like I told them, it just happens periodically.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When is the last time that you can remember going to MRCP?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: I think I went in June or July.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Just recently?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: June or July.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have plans to go back to treat with them?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Hold on.  May Or June.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are you planning on seeking further treatment with them?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have any current appointments scheduled?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Not yet because I don't have any more time right now at work.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Other than the physical therapy, did you have any other type of treatment at MRCP?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When were you typically going to these visits for physical therapy at Philly Spine and MRCP?  Was it during your workday, after work?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: No, I was getting transportation, so it was after work.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Both facilities?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: MRCP, I believe, I went one time when I was off of work.  Yeah, about two or three times I went when I was off of work when I had other appointments.  Then it was another time, I think, on the weekend or maybe after work hours, I believe.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Philly Spine was providing you transportation.  MRCP you were getting there on your own?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: I was getting there on my own.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did MRCP send you out for any diagnostic testing; x-ray, MRI, anything of that?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What did they send you for?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: They sent me for an MRI of my knees.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did they discuss the results of the MRI?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: I never went.

text: Why did you not go?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Because during the time of the accident, my job had sent me a form in reference to when I had went to go get some diagnostic tests done.  I had gave the MRI center my health insurance. I received something back from my job that said, as a result, we cannot pay for this billing because you were in a car accident at the time.  You need to forward this information to your attorney's office, and you need to discuss with the attorney's office ways to pay this because it wasn't being paid for under my insurance.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You got a denial letter for your prior MRIs from your health insurance?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: One denial letter.  That was at the time I was being represented by Simon & Simon.

text: You didn't go to get another MRI because they had denied payment?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: I didn't want the same issue to happen again.

text: But the EMG was done at Philly Spine Center.

text: But you said a male doctor came in and did that?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Correct.

text: Any other health providers or treatment providers I'm missing?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: No.

text: I seen him once in reference to this. He told me to treat my pain with Motrin and to go see a physical therapist or a chiropractor.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When was this that you saw your primary care?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: I seen him about a week or two after the accident.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Let's talk about how you're currently feeling.  I don't mean as you're sitting in the chair today, but let's just talk about in the last 30 days. Are you still getting low back pain?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How often?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: It's seven days out of a week, so maybe three or four days out of the week.  If it's seven days, it happens about four days out of the week.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Four days out of the week. How long does it last when you typically get it?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Sometimes it lasts for an hour or two. Sometimes it lasts for minutes.  If I take medication, meaning ibuprofen or Advil, it lasts for no more than a half-hour.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What would you say your pain is like in your low back when you get it on a 0 to 10 scale, 0 being no pain, 10 being the worst pain you can imagine?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: It's about an 8 or 9.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How about neck pain, are you still getting that shooting pain in your neck?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: I get it periodically.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How often?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Probably about three, four days out of the week.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What's the pain level in your neck when you get it?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: About an 8 or 9.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are you still getting knee pain?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How often?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: About four or five days out of the week.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Both of them is the same.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What's the pain level like in your knees?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Between 1 and 10?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Like a 10.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long did that take to resolve after the accident?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Probably about seven, eight months after with the exercise.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long did the bruising last after the accident?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: I'm pretty light, so it lasted for about a week or two.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did anyone ever prescribe you any medication in relation to the accident?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: No, I just took ibuprofen.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did anyone give you any sort of medical equipment to use at home?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: I received a paper of medical equipment that I can buy.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But nobody gave you anything, like a pillow or brace or anything like that?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: No.  They gave me a list of things that I can buy that I bought myself.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What did you buy?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: I bought some knee brace.  When it's cold or rainy, that's when the pain really aggravates me more.  I went to Rite Aid or Walmart and bought knee braces, things like that.  Ice packs to bring down the pain, make it easier.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you still get any swelling in your knees?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: I get swelling in my left knee.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How often does that happen?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: When it rains, if I walk too long.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Let's talk about how these injuries have affected your life.  I'm going to break that down into two different categories. First, I want to know about any activities that you were doing before this accident that you have not returned to at all since this accident. Then I'm going to ask you about activities that you still do, but you do them with some sort of pain or limitation, different from how you did them prior to the accident, okay? When I say activities, it's a very broad term.  I want you to tell me anything you do on a daily basis; grooming, chores, hobbies, social activities, relationship with your family, work, anything on a daily basis, okay?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: First, are there any activities that you completely stopped doing?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Can we take a break?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: (Whereupon, a break was taken at this time.)
I was starting to ask you about your limitations.  I think my last question was, are there any activities you were doing before the accident that you haven't returned to at all since the accident?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Well, I have two children.  I have a 13 and a 10-year-old.  Things I used to do with them before I don't do as much with them now.  I do it, but I don't do it as often as I used to.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are there any activities that you can't do at all?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: No, there's no activities I can't do at all.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Let's talk about activities you do less frequently or you do them in a different way because of your injuries?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: I don't clean my house as frequently as I used to.  I catch SEPTA transportation, so waiting by the bus stop and things like that.  I'd rather just stay in the house or sit outside than to walk to the bus stop and walk to my mom's house and go to the mall. Me and my kids used to go out to eat and things like that, but I don't do it as often as I want to.  It's limited.  I still do it, but it's just limited.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How about any specific chores at home or grooming, anything like that?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Cleaning the bathroom.  I usually go to the hairdresser every two weeks.  It's about every three weeks now.  To sit in the chair and sit underneath the dryer in that cramped space, I can't do that every two weeks.  I go when I feel up to it or basically when I can.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How about work, anything different with work?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: At work, they accommodate me a lot.  I have a chair with a pillow that sits behind me.  I can stand and sit frequently or at my leisure.  I have a step stool that my legs can rest on.  I can go to the nurse and get ice packs when I need them.  My job is really accommodating me.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Anything else that you can think of that's been changed or altered or done less frequently as a result of your injuries?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Just going out and interacting with my family.  I don't go as often as I would before.  That's life.  I mean, I go, but it's not all the time.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You mean social events with your family?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Yeah, like social events.  I can't wear heels that long.  I got to take them off and come down.  I used to wear heels for hours at a time.  Now, with these knees, I only can keep them on for about 15, 20 minutes.  After that, I got to come down to some flats or some sneakers.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Anything else you can think of?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: No, that's it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: If you think of anything else as we're going along, just let me know.
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: That's it.  Trust me.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Any other outstanding medical bills that you may have, which we'll work out with your counsel? Are there any moneys you can think of that you have paid out of pocket for in relation to the accident that you haven't been reimbursed for?
speaker: MS. SEREDA

text: Only stuff that I buy -- not buy -- have bought for my knees to help when I have to go to work or maybe I'm at an event by the pool, a knee brace and things like that.
